Welcome to the Odoo Logistic company package
!

This Odoo module optimizes your logistics and warehousing, offering a complete solution to boost efficiency and customer satisfaction across all services. It streamlines operations for everything from long-term storage to pallet management and transport. You can effortlessly manage client stock, schedule movements, ensure full traceability, optimize billing, and provide customers with real-time stock visibility.

template.p: You can access every installed App in your Odoo database on your main dashboard.

li.p: The CRM & Sales Apps handle your market research and sales orders
The Subscription App manages your fixed spaces reservation for clients
The Inventory App tracks and registers all your stock moves.
The Quality App defines the type of Quality checks to perform and register it.
The Dashboard App gives a clear overview of all operations performed for each client.
The Invoicing App manages the periodic invoicing based on the Dashboard data.
The Website App gives an overview of your activity and the portal allows your client too see their stock levels live.

h3.span: Designing an Optimized Warehouse and Operations System üì¶

template.p: By configuring the warehouse and operations, we can build a system tailored to your specific needs. This involves customizing all settings related to storage locations, packaging, stock move types, shipping connectors, and barcode configuration to ensure maximum efficiency.

div.class: o_editor_banner user-select-none o-contenteditable-false lh-1 d-flex align-items-center alert alert-info pb-0 pt-3
o_editor_banner_content o-contenteditable-true w-100 px-3

ul.li: Define your warehouse flow: Update your Warehouse Settings to choose a 1, 2, or 3-step process for receiving and shipping goods. This allows you to tailor the workflow to your specific needs, whether you prefer a simple direct transfer or a more detailed multi-step verification process.
Manage your package types: Define all the types of packages you handle (e.g., pallets, boxes). These will be used to create Storage Categories, which help you optimize warehouse space.

Set up location-based fees: In the configuration, you can define different Fee Rates and link them to specific storage locations. This lets you apply different prices to various types of storage, such as refrigerated or high-bay areas. This granular control allows for automated and accurate invoicing based on the number of pallets per fee rate.

p.em: Example: A client who had 150 pallets at ‚Ç¨0.30/day and 55 pallets at ‚Ç¨0.45/day in August.

ul.li: Create Storage Categories: Define categories that can be linked to the capacity of one or more package types.

p.em: Example: A category named "5 Std Pal" can be configured to hold five standard pallets.

ul.li: Create your stock locations: Each stock location can be linked to a storage category, a barcode, and a removal strategy. To create or update many locations at once, use the built-in import/export documentation and templates.

div.p: To boost efficiency even more, consider these topics:

li.p: Putaway Rules: Customize how products are stored based on your own rules.
Picking Optimization: Optimize picking with different methods like Batch Picking, Wave Picking, and Cluster Picking.
Connected Printer: Automate label printing by connecting your printer.
Shipping Connector: Connect with various carriers directly within Odoo.

template.p: Remember that this database is set to handle both receipts and deliveries in two steps, which directly affects how products are received and shipped out.
To receive products, you must first create a new receipt.
Here's how:

ol.li: In the Inventory App, click on Receipt and then Create a new one .
Select the scheduled receipt date and add all products with their quantities.
Click on Mark as to do.
If you have the Lot numbers available, you can add them by clicking on Details and then Import Serials/Lots.
You can either validate the receipt or manage it using a barcode scanner.
During this process, you can also place a product on a pack (like a pallet) or a pack on a larger one.
Once a receipt is confirmed, a storage operation is automatically created to put the product into stock.

template.p: The process for outbound product deliveries is similar to receiving products.
Here's how to create an outbound delivery:

ol.li: In the Inventory App, click on Pick and then Create a new one. (If your warehouse settings are configured for a one-step process, select Delivery instead.)
Select the scheduled pick date and add all products with their quantities.
Click on Mark as to do.
If you have the Lot numbers available, you can add them by clicking on Details and then Import Serials/Lots.
You can either validate the pick or manage it using a barcode scanner.
Once validated, the delivery operation will be created.
If you place products in packs, you can use the automated shipping connection with external carriers.

p.span: When you need to manually move stock‚Äîlike returning items to a quality check location or moving products after a customer validation‚Äîuse an internal transfer.

ol.li: Create a new internal transfer.
Select or scan the source location.
Select or scan the products or packages you want to move.
Select or scan the destination location.
Validate the transfer.

template.p: Use barcode scanners to validate stock movements, identify pallet positions, and perform fast, accurate stock operations. Greatly improves warehouse efficiency and reduces human error.

template.p: Here's how to invoice your customer based on operations and storage:

The dashboard provides all the necessary information, including storage occupancy, completed transfers, created packages, and performed quality checks. You just need to manually adjust the quantities on your invoices using this data.

li.p: Open the Dashboard app and go to the 3PL - Invoicing Section.
Filter by the customer you want to charge and the relevant date range.
Note: Storage data is updated daily, so it's not live. Be sure to select a date that is not today.
The dashboard provides the following reports:
Storage Report: Shows the amount of packages stored per day, broken down by fee rate.
Manutention Report: Provides details on completed transfers and the number of packages created by type and the quantity of products delivered.
Quality Report: Gives information on the number of quality checks performed.
Use this information to create your invoice:
If it's the first time invoicing, create a new invoice from the previously created Sales Order.
If you've invoiced this customer before, duplicate the previous invoice.
Add a note to the invoice specifying the invoicing period.
Update all quantities on the invoice with the numbers from the dashboard reports.
Validate the invoice.
